docs.snippet: KNAB--Klaus K., died on May 25th, 2013, at age 81. Born in Starnberg, Germany, he emigrated to the U.S. with his family at the age of eight. He was a violin prodigy; seminarian; recipient of the Distinguished Service Medal from the Air Force for h...
docs.lead_paragraph: KNAB--Klaus K., died on May 25th, 2013, at age 81. Born in Starnberg, Germany, he emigrated to the U.S. with his family at the age of eight. He was a violin prodigy; seminarian; recipient of the Distinguished Service Medal from the Air Force for his service during the Korean conflict; teacher of Latin, Greek and AP English; West Coast sales rep for several publishers, and sales manager for Simon & Schuster. Leaving publishing in 1984, Klaus became a brilliant, self-taught wood-carver, working in shallow relief; a gourd artist, using natural, narrative, and abstract themes, and a wire portraitist of people and animals. His works are in private collections on both coasts. Klaus loved opera and baseball, basketball and track; fine art; puns; chamber music; poetry, history and biography, good food, and the beautiful Oregon coast. A warm and generous friend, a loving husband, father, brother, and grandfather, he was a man of integrity and honesty, incapable of guile. Klaus was diagnosed with esophageal cancer in December, 2012, and faced his inevitable end with characteristic grace, dignity and humor. He showed the rest of us how to do it. He leaves behind his grieving family: his wife of 36 years, Linda Zuckerman; his children, Michael, Thomas and Jude; his granddaughter, Kristi; his sister, Judith, and his brothers, Bernard and Christopher; his friends, and the many people whose lives were made richer for knowing him. Contributions in Klaus's memory may be made to: Compassion & Choices of Oregon, PO Box 6404, Portland, OR 97228, or to the charity of your choice.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  KNAB, KLAUS K.

docs.abstract: Cyc, indoor cycling gym in Austin, Tex, is first fitness company to specifically target college students, demographic more traditionally associated with sleeping through a class than sweating through one.

docs.snippet: The hot topic in wedding circles this year? Whether to request, remind or even require that guests go cold turkey on cellphones, cameras and other such technology during the event....
docs.lead_paragraph: The hot topic in wedding circles this year? Whether to request, remind or even require that guests go cold turkey on cellphones, cameras and other such technology during the event.
docs.abstract: Bruce Feiler This Life column observes that more brides and grooms are requesting guests to leave cell phones, cameras and other technology behind during their wedding to avoid spoiling the event.

docs.snippet: The topsy-turvy world of the markets — particularly the ultralow yield of bonds — is upending what many people thought they knew about saving for retirement....
docs.lead_paragraph: The topsy-turvy world of the markets — particularly the ultralow yield of bonds — is upending what many people thought they knew about saving for retirement.
docs.abstract: Jeff Sommer Strategies column holds that topsy-turvy world of the markets is upending what many people thought they knew about saving for retirement; notes that conventional wisdom says people should hold more bonds as they age, but ultralow interest rates have left many would-be retirees with big problem that they might exhaust their bond portfolios before they die.

headline.seo: Why Many Retirees Could Outlive a $1 Million Nest Egg
